p:
E-caryophyllene (a sesquiterpene hydrocarbon) was the main chemical constituent of the essential oils of M. divaricatum and C. sylvestris. According to Santos et al.
15 , essential oils rich in sesquiterpenes, mainly E-caryophyllene, showed variable levels of activity against promastigote forms of Leishmania with IC 50 values in the range between 5 and 22 Âµg/mL. Thus, our essential oils showed an antiparasitic potency similar to those described in the literature.
